Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1) Status of the updated gender policy 2) The status of development of National Gender Action Plan 3) # of institutions with gender responsive sectoral plans and policies 4) # of CEDAW periodic report prepared and submitted

baseline.comment: 1) 2004 Gender policy available 2) Draft National Gender Action Plan in Place 3) 5 line ministries with gender responsive sectoral plans and policies 4) Draft 3rd CEDAW report available

target.comment: *Draft National Gender Action Plan in Place *2 line ministries with gender responsive sectoral plans and policies *Draft 3rd CEDAW report available

actual.comment: As per the agreed annual work plan, the expected deliverables for the reporting year is fully achieved. Key achievements are: - 5th CEDAW report prepared and submitted to CEDAW secretariat, - Socio-economic study on Eritrean women conducted and report produced. The study was conducted to assess in-depth situation of women and look for possibilities and opportunities available to assist women in improving their economic wellbeing. - Country review report on Beijing +20 report produced and it will be reviewed and endorsed at the upcoming 2015 United Nations Commission on the Status of Women meeting on the implementation of the Beijing Declaration and Plat form for Action, - Final report on 2nd National Gender Action Plan prepared and validation workshop with all stakeholders conducted, - 7th National Union of Eritrean Women (NUEW) congress conducted on 16 and 17 September 2014. The participants of the congressional meeting elected members who would lead the Assembly for the coming 4 years and take stock of the achievements of NUEW for the last ten years. Simultaneously, International Symposium on peace and economic empowerment under the theme "Justice is our Motto and Equality is our Goal" was organized with the participation of a wide range of women leaders from COMESA and abroad, who have been in the forefront of women empowerment in different capacities; in government, private sector and NON-Government Organizations and Eritrean in diaspora. - FGM mapping exercise in 13 villages in two regions (Gash Barka and Anseba) conducted and final report prepared, - Sectoral policy review for Ministry of Transport and communication and Ministry of Information to identify gender gaps conducted, gender mainstreaming strategy and action plan drafted. - Flagship report on the achievements towards gender equality in Eritrea for the last ten years prepared. - Nationwide awareness and advocacy campaigns on the concept of gender, gender equality, harmful traditional practices

target.comment: *Develop 10 years Strategic and Action Plans *Review and analyse gender mainstreaming strategies of MOE, MOA *Develop 5 years National Strategic Plan on abandonment FGM/C using findings from various studies and researches

location.name: Serejeka
location.activity-description:
Sub Region Serejeka ( Embadorho, Weki, Guritat,Dekseb, Hayelo......... Villages)
The project will create enabling environment (policy, capacity, knowledge, alternatives) necessary for adoption of Sustainable Land Management SLM) practices and alleviate environmental degradation while improving live

location.name: Maekel Region
location.activity-description:
Maekel Region
1. Land distribution 2. Institution capacity building 3. Incentives for marginal lands 4. Income generating activities 5. Affirestation

result.title: Objective
result.description: To create the enabling environment (policy, capacity, knowledge, alternatives) necessary for adoption of sustainable LM practices and alleviate environmental degradation while improving livelihoods of the farming communities of the CHZ.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. % decrease of degraded land area in Serejeka sub-zoba
-

baseline.comment:
Relevant baseline values to be established during inception phase; measure of current extent of land degradation will include, but will not be limited to:
- Land area (ha) of sub-zoba with signs of soil erosion
- Ha of land area deforested, using long-term time series
- Liters of water abstraction for agricultural use (irrigation) per ha (distribution map)
- Soil fertility levels (baselines to be established at pilot village level); relevant measures to be determined
- Level of NRM yields (e.g. crops)

target.comment: Overall 25% decrease in degraded area; individual targets to be developed as per established measure during inception period

actual.comment:
Total highly/severe degraded land was 16,180ha (Baseline).
Due to better land tenure system, introduction of land management, improved irrigation system and afforestation the degraded land relatively stabilised and reduced by 11% on crop lands and 12% on open access grazing land converted to community forest/woodlots.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Ha of land under new (private) land tenure arrangements. No. of villages and area of land covered

baseline.comment: Currently the 1994 Land Proclamation is not applied and 0 ha of land in the Serejeka sub-zoba are under long-term private ownership/ tenure

target.comment: More than 50% of land in the sub-zoba are under private title, following the provisions of the 1994 Land Proclamation

actual.comment: 1,327.5 ha of agricultural land are put under the new (private) land tenure arrangements which belongs to 5 villages.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Decrease of population living below the poverty line in Serejeka sub-zoba

baseline.comment: Currently 66% of the population in Serejeka sub-zoba live below the poverty line (according to the international definition of poverty; assessed in xxx through xxx

target.comment: The poverty rate is reduced to at least 40% in the sub-zoba

actual.comment: At this stage there is no concrete information/data available in poverty reduction, however, proxy estimates in the project area suggests that poverty has reduced slightly due to expansion of irrigation system by 60%, increase in agricultural production and other income generating interventions like horticulture, sale of vegetables from improved irrigation system and sale of timbers from afforestation interventions.

target.comment: Overall 25% decrease in degraded area; individual targets to be developed as per established measure during inception period

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Replicable models of SLM are developed and representative communities use them to manage land in 28 villages of the central highland that are representative of the major agro-ecological zone for central highlands, reducing the rate of land degradation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 4. % Increase in land (ha) managed through community-level SLM plans

baseline.comment:
Currently no community-level SLM plans are in place
No of villages with functional SLM plans in place
Area (ha) managed through application of SLM plans

target.comment: The management of land in Serejeka sub-zoba is guided by community level SLM plans (the Serejeka sub-zoba constitutes approximately 240,000 ha and 28 villages are situated in the sub-zoba)

actual.comment:
No of villages with functional SLM plans in place: 5 villages out of 28 (5/28) which covers 18% of the total project area are in place with SLM plan.
Area (ha) managed through application of SLM plans: Total area covered is 1974ha ( Crop land 1005ha and community woodlots 970ha) this indicates 9% increment from baseline.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 5. Ratio of source of household incomes in the 28 pilot villages - income from agriculture versus other alternative income sources

baseline.comment: Baseline is established. Ratio of source of household incomes in the pilot villages i.e.; income from agriculture versus other alternative income sources follows the following pattern: 75% of the source of income is derived from agriculture while 25% comes from off farm employment and remittance.

target.comment: Ratios clearly indicate income diversification (as a measure of resilience); final targets to be established during inception phase

actual.comment: No quantitative available data for this indicator, however, the proxy indicators shows that increased income generating activities such as bee keeping, expansion of woodlots and sale, cash income from dales of timber, expansion of irrigated crops (Vegetables) enhanced diversification of income sources and attributed to increase agricultural production.The proportion of source of household incomes in the pilot villages from agriculture versus other alternative income sources has shown slight shift from baseline situation. Estimated 5% increment is observed.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 6. No. of households in 28 pilot villages benefiting from application of Land Proclamation

baseline.comment: Currently the 1994 Land Proclamation is not applied and 0 households in the pilot area are currently benefiting from its application

target.comment: More than 50% of rural/ land based households benefit from private tenure, following the provisions of the 1994 Land Proclamation

actual.comment: Land distribution is conducted in five villages and the zero baseline has increased by 23% which is 3313 HH out of 13223 households(HH)) has benefited from the new private land tenure system and sustainable land management practices.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: A system of knowledge management (KM) for SLM is developed and used to achieve SLM through mainstreaming of SLM principles into the regional and national development programs, projects, strategies, policies and legislation

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 7. Increased knowledge about SLM practices amongst all project key stakeholders/ SLM platform members

baseline.comment: Knowledge baseline to be established during KCAS development during inception phase (Knowledge & Awareness survey amongst representative sample of key stakeholder groups)

target.comment: 50% of population in 28 pilot villages and 100% of all extension personnel reach knowledge and awareness target (set after baseline survey)

actual.comment: 16960/53220 (32%) community members participated in sustainable land management awareness programmes in all 28 villages and 65% of extension personnel received trainings and acquired good knowledge and awareness of sustainable Land management principles. Besides practical and theoretical training on basic GPS application was conducted for 10 days. for 23 staffs from Ministry of Agriculture who are directly involved in the land distribution and mapping.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 8. Coordinated SLM KM â€œplatformâ€ operational and self sustaining

baseline.comment: No formal SLM-KM â€œplatformâ€ exists to date

target.comment: A minimum of 7 SLM-KM â€œplatformsâ€ established (1 national, 3 regional and 3 sub-regional)

actual.comment: NO PROGRESS, however,continuous consultative meetings has been organised with community/village land distribution committee and sub zobas for smooth implementation of land distribution.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 9. Evidence of successful mainstreaming of SLM principles in key policies

baseline.comment: The existing draft land use policy does not integrate SLM principles and standards

target.comment: SLM fully integrated (mainstreamed) into the new, approved land use policy

actual.comment: NO PROGRESS

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 10. Zoba and sub-zoba annual budgets (in target area) include allocations for replication/adoption of SLM models to new villages and for the extension and implementation of SLM activities

baseline.comment: Baseline information on Zobas and sub zobas budget allocated to SLM practices will be determined during the inception phase

target.comment: 40 % increment on their budget for SLM practices

actual.comment: There is no quantitative data allocation of resources for SLM replication/adoption of SLM models. However, reports ( Secondary information) indicates that the government and the sub region invest on sustainable land management practices such as check dams, catchment treatment, afforestation and soil and water conservations. Sub region allocated 2-3 million ERN for the establishment of four nursery stations for tree seedling production to be distributed to communities in the project area. The nursery can produce over 1.2 million seedlings a year. Sub Zoba covers all related costs/expenses of production and transportation.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Capacity building programs and adaptive management systems are developed at all levels for improved governance of SLM, particularly enabling grass root community to implement improved SLM

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 11. % of annual increase in budget available for implementation of Capacity Support Strategy and Action plan (CSSAP) (in pilot area)

baseline.comment: Baseline value for CSSAP implementation to be determined during CSSAP

target.comment: Annual increase of at least 15% (target value to be verified during baseline assessment) including from co-financing sources

actual.comment: Organisational system on forestry/ enclosures, water and irrigation, farm land management at village level has been developed. A draft bylaw has been prepared as working reference for the committee. Besides continuous training on SLM principles and applications has peen provided to all concerned committees.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 12. No. of individuals that apply the through the project developed extension packages

baseline.comment: No extension package available; baseline of people who apply packages is 0%

target.comment: 80% of all land managers in the 28 pilot villages use the packages; additionally more than 150 land managers in â€œreplicateâ€ areas do so; 100% of extension officers in Maekel zoba are knowledgeable about the extension packages and use them in their extension work

actual.comment: As an extension package improved seed varieties has already been distributed ( wheat, potatoes) also plant protection chemicals (pesticides/insecticides) supplied. Almost in all villages the natural resource conservation activities like terracing, afforestation, farm land terracing ...........,animal health service undertaken in the project area.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 13. Ratio of U$ leveraged through SLM relevant carbon finance project (s) and reinvestment into CCA activities in pilot area

baseline.comment: Currently no SLM relevant carbon finance project identified

target.comment: At least one project identified, prepared and under implementation

actual.comment: No progress

result.title: Outcome 4
result.description: Learning, evaluation, and adaptive management increased

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 14. Level of performance score achieved in scheduled evaluations

baseline.comment: Project design: to establish performance score (use GEF BD score as guidance)

target.comment: A minimum of satisfactory performance (approx. 50% of all scheduled activities implemented to plan) at mid-term of project ; at least 90% at end of project

actual.comment: No progress.

location.name: Anseba Region
location.activity-description:
Hamelmalo and Habero ( Anseba Region)
1. Ground Water Recharge 2. Soil and Water Conservation Activities 3. Construction of Micro dams and Sub surface dams. 4. Solar Irrigation 3. Establish Metrological Stations

location.name: Anseba Region
location.activity-description:
Hamelmalo (Wazentet , Gebsi....... villages) and Habero (Aretay, Fiza, ...... villages)
1) Food production and productivity increased through technology transfer, 2) Land productivity increased through water harvesting and management , diversification and intensification of production under irrigat

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Amount of water harvested increased from subsurface and microdams with associated pumping and irrigation water distribution facilities. 2. Tonnes of harvest/ production increased. 3. No of policy/plans/strategies recised or developed as a result of policy advocacy activities.

baseline.comment: 1. Due to climate change impact the sub zoba hamelmalo and Habero observed variablity in temprature resulting water stress. 2. In the programme area seasonal and multi-year droughts are more frequent than in the past resulting very low agricultural production. 3.Existing policies and plans not uptodated.

target.comment: - Construction of two micro dams - Introduction of drought, heat tolerant seeds - Construction of one diversion structures - Distribution of 400 units of energy efficient improved stoves to female headed households

actual.comment: -Two full set of solar irrigation installed to irrigate 50 Ha. Of land which is situated in the downstream part of the existing two wells in sub zoba Habero. -Nursery site which has a potential of propagating half a million of different types of seedlings rehabilitated and established. -In Two site of sub zoba Habero (Fiza and Lemayte) construction of diversion structure completed. -Two micro dams constructed in sub zoba Hamelmalo. Both micro dams in Gebsi and Wazentet with a capacity of 120,000 M3 and 300,000 M3 respectively completed. Both dams have a potential of irrigating 50 Ha. - Drought resistant, heat tolerant and early matured crops introduced - 400 female headed households (2000 individuals) provided with improved energy effeciency stoves in sub zoba Hamelmalo and Habero -

target.comment: - Metrological stations in six sites within the zobaAnseba installed and operationalized - Soil and water conservation activities conducted

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
# of months the target households feed themselves from own harvest
# of HHs engaged in bee keeping as an income generating activity

baseline.comment:
• Mean number of months that households are able to feed themselves from their harvest is between 2 & 4 months (Baseline Survey-Emergency Response Addressing Livelihoods, 2010)
• All the targeted households depend on crops and/or livestock for their source of income

target.comment: 3150 HH beneficiaries will be supported through constructing three check dams in Afabet sub-zone, Amaro, Alda and Mesagid and distribution of improved seeds and initial restocking support.

actual.comment: UNDP has supported in recovering the region’s food security and livelihoods activities through construction of check-dams, distribution of improved seeds and initial restocking support. The UNDP project has enabled the communities to have water access for their livestock and domestic use in the semi-arid area of the sub-zone. the above targeted three micro-dams have been successfully completed. Above 3150 HHs have benefited from the intervention. It was a new experience for the community and it has leveraged to change the nomadic population to semi-sedentary life style. The check-dams built have increased the underground water table and the community can also dug downstream well for human drink. However, as the check-dams built are small in size the harvested water can last for 2 or 3 months.Improved seeds have been provided to about 4700 people and about 2000 small ruminants have been purchased but they will be distributed to beneficiaries at the beginning of the coming year. The dairy goats are expected to produce milk and improve nutrition of under- 5 children of the target households. Besides, the intervention is expected to improve the household income of the target households by selling offspring of the goats.

target.comment: Secure access of water in Afentra, Gash Barka region and Unalalai, Maekel regions and support Debub region in soil and water conservation including construction of check dams through community participation. Support will also be given to drought and locust affected Northern and Southern Red Sea regions.

actual.comment: Water sources (micro-dams) have been built in Gash Barka region, Afentra village and Maekel region in Unalali village to supplement the rain fed agriculture of the regions. The micro-dams will be used for livestock drink, small sacle irrigation and domestic use. It is expected that the micro-dams will boost the underground water table, providing potential to sink a downstream well for human consumption. UNDP has also supported seven villages in sub-region of Maimine, Debub region in soil and water conservation activities. Heavily eroded land and gullies created by floods and water run offs were treated with soil and water conservation structures, such as gabion, dry masonry check dams and terraces. The project has increased food supply and security by improving purchasing capacity of target population through cash for work and has met some basic needs of the farmers in response to this year’s crop harvest failure and motivated women and youth to participate in employment generating activities. 10,384 beneficiaries (51% female) of which 84,190 people have received improved seeds for the coming rainy season, and about 1000 small ruminants (3 for each beneficiary) distributed to 333 households (1,665 people) based on the already established criteria by the local authorities. The distribution which includes pregnant dairy goats and improved seeds are expected to alleviate the food problems of the affected population immediately and also sustain the livelihoods of the communities beyond the project life. Without this support, the situation of the affected communities may have been precarious and may turn from bad to worse. The small ruminants are locally adapted breeds to help acquire resistance to diseases and harsh climate.

These local communities will be participating in planning and management, especially identifying and implementing adapt

result.title: Objective
result.description: Create policy and institutional conditions to operationalize the national protected area system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Total annual government financing for management and conservation of national protected area system.

baseline.comment: Baseline: US$ 0

target.comment:
Target: US$ 1,000,000/annual*
* cumulative for national PA administration and individual PA management

actual.comment: US$: 150,000 is the total annual government financing for management and conservation of national protected area system for the reporting year:

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Total hectares legally designated as a national protected area conforming to basic IUCN standards/categories

baseline.comment:
Terrestrial: 0
Marine: 0

target.comment:
Terrestrial: 649,100 ha
Marine: 360,000 ha

actual.comment:
Terrestrial: 0
Marine: 0
So far no legal protected area policy and institutional framework to operationalize national protected area systems has been prepared thus no legally designated national protected area has been established as no regulatory framework has been prepared yet. Formulation of this regulatory framework is planned to be initiated in the fourth quarter of 2015 and consultation is under way to facilitate the process.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Total hectares of critical habitat conserved within newly established national protected areas.

baseline.comment:
Hectares of:
Native highland forest: 0
Native mangrove: 0
African wild ass habitat: 0
Turtle nesting sites: 0
Sea grass: 0

target.comment:
Hectares of:
Native highland forest: 55,000 Native mangrove: 12,000
African wild ass habitat: 80,000
Turtle nesting sites: 1300
Sea grass: 2,300

actual.comment: No progress. Conservation of critical habitat could not be implemented as so far no legal framework was formulated as indicated earlier.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Establishment of protected area policy and institutional frameworks to operationalize national protected areas system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National government law/proclamation legalizing the application of IUCN based designations for establishment of terrestrial and marine protected areas.

baseline.comment: Baseline: 0

target.comment: Target: 1

actual.comment:
Achievement todate: 0
No progress as formulation of the legal framework is not yet realized.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Generation of SLM/SFM capacity required to support national system of protected areas

Women: 0

Women: 750

actual.comment:
Men: 0
Women: 0
No farm/fisheries field (FFS) schools have yet been establised.

baseline.comment:
FFS households: 0
FFS Women: 0

target.comment:

actual.comment: No FFS households and FFS women groups have been established yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of farm and fishing field school participants adopting ecosystem conservation practices as detailed in the community ecosystem services conservation plans.

baseline.comment: Baseline: 0

target.comment: Target: 1,000

actual.comment: Achievement todate: 0; as no community ecosystem services conservation plans have been prepared as of yet.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Total hectares of native forest cover within the Green Belt.

baseline.comment: Baseline: 31,680 ha

target.comment: Target: 55,000 ha

actual.comment: mapping and zoning within the protected area are not yet started; no measurement of forest cover has been conducted yet, and plantation of seedlings is to be done during this rainy season (July-August, 2015).

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Surface water quality/quantity of main upland streams improved to more closely meet needs of natural ecosystem function.

baseline.comment: Water quality/quantity target sites and baseline standards TBD at inception

target.comment: Water quality/quantity target sites and standards TBD at inception.

actual.comment: Not initiated yet but equipment and materials for the activity have been identified and procurement plan is in place and is planned to be implemented before the end of 2015.
